awd_titl_txt: RII Track-2 FEC: Resilience Informatics for the Convergence of Critical Capacities to Address Regional-scale Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Major advancements in technology, data computation power, and theory are converging in the ecological profession at a time of great uncertainty for humanity. Many ecosystems are experiencing rapid and sudden collapses and transitioning to less productive ecosystem states, threatening fundamental ecosystem services upon which humanity relies. Food and water security, rural economies, water rights, wildfire disaster avoidance, even funding for public school education are all threatened as a result of simple transitions in vegetation occurring at a rate and geographic scope that is unmatched during the lives of previous generations. This project will build critical expertise and leverage technology in new ways to confront the grand challenge of management to avoid large, regional-scale transitions in vegetation. Resilience theory and the formal study of regime shifts in nature have been foundational science pursuits for nearly 50 years in of ecology, and technology and computational power are now at a point that allows launch of the next level of analysis in the study and application of resilience science. This project will develop resilience informatics screening tools for more advanced and earlier detection of vegetation transitions.  The project will create critical capacities to explore this new and transformative informatics approach into social governance structures and thus improve options for avoiding critical transitions in social-ecological systems.


Tracking and predicting large-scale ecosystem transitions are of national and international importance and key to securing the future livelihoods, personal security, food security, and water security of diverse populations in a changing world. This research converges faculty from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the University of Montana with a shared vision - to build sufficient capacity to address the grand challenge of avoiding undesirable transitions in ecological systems that are so severe that their consequences go beyond the traditions of any one individual investigator's disciplinary expertise. We propose a spatial informatics approach that links recent advances in resilience theory with a state-of-the-art rangeland landcover and analysis dataset, and a powerful cloud-computing platform, as screening tools for more advanced and earlier detection of regime shifts across ecosystems. At the same time, we propose basic social science research to better understand the barriers and opportunities to applying innovative technological approaches to build resilience across working lands. We will leverage emerging, big-data approaches to social and behavioral data analysis to pioneer an approach for rapid and strategic identification of individuals and social groups with increased willingness and capacity to address future regime shifts and other environmental challenges of national priority. Our collaboration of social and biophysical science faculty will engage with collaborative landscape governance processes in Nebraska and Montana, include groups of resource users and managers, and translate this knowledge into proactive strategies for addressing various scales of ecological change before it occurs, through adaptation and resilience-building processes. This collaboration is built on five key convergence points which establish: a platform for sustaining research productivity through recruitment and training of early-career faculty; a nationally-recognized resilience-science education program; and greater access to cyberinfrastructure among public and private stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The vision for our EPSCoR project was to improve the ability for humanity to navigate undesirable transitions such as the transition from grasslands to woodlands in the US Great Plains. Successful navigation of such transitions avoids the severe social-ecological consequences resulting from them. We leveraged newly available technology and computation power to develop a transition screening tool capable of detecting shifts in vegetation across the United States over time. This tool is now available to all through the Rangeland Analysis Platform (https://rangelands.app/). With this and the use of big data to identify patterns in nature and human communities, our project team showed stakeholders how they can use the screening tool to spot vegetation transitions and use resilience theory to help counteract them. 

We confirmed our methodology could be applied for a series of locations and (1) identified the vegetation transition that was of greatest concern or most expected, (2) detected the presence of signals where locations were likely to exhibit transitions, (3) differentiated transient signals of vegetation response from more persistent signals of vegetation transition, (4) determined whether persistent transition signals were stationary or nonstationary over time, and (5) repeated the process to screen for additional transitions in rangeland vegetation that were of lesser concern, not expected, or unknown a priori. This flexible methodology allowed professionals to image spatial regime boundaries, track the magnitude and direction of transitions, differentiate persistent signals from more-concerning persistent and moving transition signals, and leverage disciplinary strengths and resources for inventory and monitoring and management of transitions.

We conducted a survey of 1,473 rangeland conservation professionals in Nebraska and Montana about their perceptions of vegetation transitions. We found that observing woody encroachment and understanding the risks associated with it were significant in predicting a positive attitude toward adapting to related challenges. We analyzed the extent to which ranchers' social networks affected whether they sought information and adopted technology to address harmful changes in vegetation on their land. We found that education, risk perception, and a spillover effect of transitions affecting their neighbors’ properties all positively influenced them to seek information and adopt technology. Age had a negative impact. The risk attitude variable indicated that the willingness to adopt informatics technology would increase with risk-seeking behavior. We identified two groups of ranchers that would be most likely to use prescribed burns: (1) ranchers with networks made up of mostly other ranchers and (2) ranchers with more occupationally diverse networks.

Our goal in the area of converging science and policy was to explore how resilience informatics could assist agency professionals and policymakers in closing the science-policy gap. We led a series of workshops to foster more proactive policy and management to better deal with drivers of vegetation transitions known to be of national concern. Products were used for statewide policy discussions of a Cheatgrass Challenge in Montana and a new initiative for woody encroachment in Nebraska. The products were successful in guiding more anticipatory action to undesired vegetation change and demand grew for customized products in surrounding EPSCoR states.

Regarding workforce development and broader societal impacts, we developed more customizable and responsive technological delivery and science visualization for stakeholder use. We held workshops that facilitated co-production and emphasized needs for technology and data to be customized in a way accessible to rural citizens. We built an online educational clearinghouse for the development and deployment of educational materials on resilience applications and we provided greater cyberinfrastructure access. We and partners developed technologies used to screen for severe transitions in rangeland vegetation. These breakthroughs resulted in high demand to interface with industry, government, and the public, a key focus of this EPSCOR project regarding workforce development. Twenty-three meetings were held with landowners and agencies, totaling about 355 attendees from rancher groups, the USDA-NRCS, USFS, USFWS, The Nature Conservancy, state agencies, the BLM and others. Following these meetings, we further customized products.

In terms of human capital, our EPSCoR project supported two senior-career researchers, eight early-career researchers, eight postdoctoral research associates, two doctoral students, and one master’s student. Eleven researchers were male and nine were female. At the start of their participation in the project, the female researchers held positions from master’s student to early-career researcher. By the end of the project, six of the nine female researchers had advanced to the next level in their career trajectory. Five of the 11 male researchers had also advanced to the next level in their career trajectory. Four early-career researchers advanced to senior researchers. In addition, one of these four advanced from an assistant professor to an associate professor early in the grant and was promoted to full professor in August 2024. Four postdoctoral researchers advanced to early-career researchers. Our students successfully completed their degrees and have moved on to become post-doctoral researchers and doctoral students.
